case_name: Appellant v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th August, 1953, of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th August, 1953, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1951 arising out of the judgment and order dated the 31st July, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Allahabad in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949.

facts.text: Judgment and order dated the 31st July, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Allahabad in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 31st July, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Allahabad in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949. P. Sinha and B. C. Misra, for the appellant. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the respondent. 1957. October 14.

facts.text: Appellant charged under ss. 408 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant bad been charged under ss. 408 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code, and tried by jury of 5. The jury returned a unanimous verdict of number guilty. The learned Additional Sessions Judge accepted the verdict of the jury and acquitted the accused.

facts.text: Tried by jury of 5.

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of number guilty. The learned Additional Sessions Judge accepted the verdict of the jury and acquitted the accused. On appeal by the Government of Uttar Pradesh, the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted the appellant under the sections aforesaid, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code, and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively.

facts.text: Jury returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge accepted the verdict of the jury and acquitted the accused. On appeal by the Government of Uttar Pradesh, the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted the appellant under the sections aforesaid, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code, and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively.

facts.text: Learned Additional Sessions Judge accepted the verdict of the jury and acquitted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the Government of Uttar Pradesh, the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted the appellant under the sections aforesaid, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code, and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively. Out of the fine, if realized, seven thousand rupees was directed to be paid to the Imperial Bank of India, Allahabad, as companypensation.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court set aside the order of acquittal and convicted the appellant under ss. 408 and 477A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the Government of Uttar Pradesh, the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted the appellant under the sections aforesaid, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code, and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively.

facts.text: Sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees under s. 408 IPC, and four years under s. 477A IPC, consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code, and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively. Out of the fine, if realized, seven thousand rupees was directed to be paid to the Imperial Bank of India, Allahabad, as companypensation.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal obtained by order dated December 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer for a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court was refused. The appellant moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal by order dated December 15, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant was employed as a clerk by the Imperial Bank at Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we take of the legality of the trial in this case, it is number necessary to go into the details of the prosecution case except to state that the appellant was charged under the sections aforesaid, for having companymitted criminal breach of trust in respect of valuable securities amounting to Rs. 7,410 odd of the Imperial Bank at Allahabad, while in the employment of the Bank as a clerk, and had in that capacity, with intent to defraud, destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and other papers during January to July, 1946.

facts.text: Criminal breach of trust in respect of valuable securities amounting to Rs. 7,410 odd.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was charged under the sections aforesaid, for having companymitted criminal breach of trust in respect of valuable securities amounting to Rs. 7,410 odd of the Imperial Bank at Allahabad, while in the employment of the Bank as a clerk, and had in that capacity, with intent to defraud, destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and other papers during January to July, 1946.

facts.text: Destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and other papers during January to July, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: while in the employment of the Bank as a clerk, and had in that capacity, with intent to defraud, destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and other papers during January to July, 1946. facts.text: High Court judgment comprising about 130 typed pages.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal

facts.text: Case involved large volume of documentary evidence almost all in English.

anchor.surface_text: This case involved a companysideration of a large volume of documentary evidence almost all in English. The oral evidence was directed mainly to companynect those documents and to explain their bearing on the charges framed against the accused, of criminal breach of trust and falsification of relevant accounts and entries in the registers maintained by the Bank.

facts.text: Mr. Ganguli, prosecution witness No. 26 - Agent of the Bank - examined on 12 days between October and December, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ganguli, prosecution witness No. 26 -Agent of the Bank-was examined at great length, and be gave his evidence on 12 days between October and December, 1949, It runs into about 45 typed pages.

facts.text: High Court found that out of five jurors, three had sufficient knowledge of English, fourth knew very little, fifth had insufficient knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the five jurors selected by the learned Sessions Judge, three had sufficient knowledge of English, fourth knew very little English and companyld number read the documents produced in the case and the fifth also had number sufficient knowledge of English he companyld understand a letter written in English with some difficulty and companyld number read English newspapers.

facts.text: Two jurors, Shri Sheik Ashique Ali and Shri Farman Ali, were not in a position to decide the question of authorship of the forged documents satisfactorily.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the two jurors, Shri Sheik Ashique Ali and Shri Farman Ali, were number in a position to decide the question of authorship of the forged documents satisfactorily.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside.

facts.text: Offence committed about eleven years ago before 1957 judgment.

holdings.text: though the memorandum of appeal filed in the High Court was wholly inadequate, the defect was not such as to render it null and void so as to entitle the High Court to reject it in limine

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the first contention, it is enough to say that though the memorandum of appeal filed in the High Court was wholly inadequate, the defect was not such as to render it null and void so as to entitle the High Court to reject it in limine. The point arises in this way Apart from the prayer,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Memorandum inadequate but complies minimally with s.419 CrPC requirements; not null and void despite lacking specific errors of law under s.418

holdings.text: we must express our disapproval of any such practice as has been referred to in the judgment below. A memorandum of appeal is meant to be a succinct statement of the grounds upon which the appellant proposes to support the appeal

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the High Court was correct in its appreciation of the legal position, even so, we must express our disapproval of any such practice as has been referred to in the judgment below. A memorandum of appeal is meant to be a succinct statement of the grounds upon which the appellant proposes to support the appeal. It is a notice to the Court that such and such specific grounds are proposed to be urged on behalf of the appellant,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bald grounds like 'against weight of evidence' waste time and surprise parties; better practice requires specific grounds for efficient justice

holdings.text: On that finding, it is clear that the appellants contention that it was a trial coram non judice is well-founded

anchor.surface_text: On that finding, it is clear that the appellants contention that it was a trial coram non judice is well-founded. This case is analogous to the case of Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor 1 , which went up to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, from a judgment of the Patna High Court confirming the conviction and the sentences of the accused persons on a charge of murder and rioting.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the legal position in the instant case is the same

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships opinion, this is necessarily the correct view. They think that the effect of the incompetence of a juror is to deny to the accused an essential part of the protection accorded to him by law and that the result of the trial in the present case was a clear miscarriage of justice. ... In our opinion, the legal position in the instant case is the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ras Behari Lal: juror incompetence denies legal protection, causes miscarriage of justice regardless of case complexity

holdings.text: irrespective of the result, it was no trial at all The question of prejudice does not arise because it is not a mere irregularity. but a case of mis-trial

anchor.surface_text: It was., however, argued on behalf of the State Government that in the instant case, the jury had returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty and that, therefore, there was no prejudice to the accused persons. ... the position is clear in law that irrespective of the result, it was no trial at all The question of prejudice does not arise because it is not a mere irregularity. but a case of mis-trial, as the Judicial Committee put it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incompetent jury makes it mistrial/coram non judice, not irregularity; unanimous verdict irrelevant, no prejudice inquiry needed

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the first contention, it is enough to say that though the memorandum of appeal filed in the High Court was wholly inadequate, the defect was not such as to render it null and void so as to entitle the High Court to reject it in limine. The point arises in this way Apart from the prayer,

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside. We do number express any opinion on the question whether it is a fit case for a de numbero trial by a companypetent jury or by a Court of Session without a jury, if the present state of the law permits it.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding, it is clear that the appellants contention that it was a trial coram non judice is well-founded. This case is analogous to the case of Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor 1 , which went up to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, from a judgment of the Patna High Court confirming the conviction and the sentences of the accused persons on a charge of murder and rioting.

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside. We do number express any opinion on the question whether it is a fit case for a de numbero trial by a companypetent jury or by a Court of Session without a jury, if the present state of the law permits it.

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships opinion, this is necessarily the correct view. They think that the effect of the incompetence of a juror is to deny to the accused an essential part of the protection accorded to him by law and that the result of the trial in the present case was a clear miscarriage of justice. ... In our opinion, the legal position in the instant case is the same.

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside. We do number express any opinion on the question whether it is a fit case for a de numbero trial by a companypetent jury or by a Court of Session without a jury, if the present state of the law permits it.

anchor.surface_text: It was., however, argued on behalf of the State Government that in the instant case, the jury had returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty and that, therefore, there was no prejudice to the accused persons. ... the position is clear in law that irrespective of the result, it was no trial at all The question of prejudice does not arise because it is not a mere irregularity. but a case of mis-trial, as the Judicial Committee put it.

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside. We do number express any opinion on the question whether it is a fit case for a de numbero trial by a companypetent jury or by a Court of Session without a jury, if the present state of the law permits it.
